events.event_description: Virginia became the top net electricity recipient state, bringing in 50.1 million megawatthours (36% of its total supply) from other states.
events.citation: In 2023, utilities in Virginia brought in the most electricity from other states, with 50.1 million megawatthours (MWh) in net electricity interstate receipts, or 36% of the state's total electricity supply.

events.event_description: Pennsylvania became the largest electricity exporter, shipping out 83.4 million MWh (26% of its generation) to other states.
events.citation: Generators in Pennsylvania moved the most electricity outside state borders in 2023, with 83.4 million MWh of power shipped out, or 26% of generation in Pennsylvania.

events.event_description: Washington state shifted from being a net electricity producer to receiving 1.1 million MWh from other states, experiencing a 22% decrease in electricity generation due to drought.
events.citation: Utilities in Washington went from producing more electricity than customers consumed to receiving over 1.1 million MWh of electricity from other states, a one-year turnaround of 25.1 million MWh in 2023. The ongoing drought in Canada and Washington reduced hydroelectric generation for both regions.

events.event_description: California experienced a significant 28.3 million MWh decrease in electricity receipts due to reduced consumption and increased hydroelectric generation.
events.citation: The 28.3 million MWh decrease in electricity receipts in 2023 in California was mainly due to a 5% (12.4 million MWh) decrease in electricity consumption and an 84% (14.7 million MWh) increase in hydroelectric generation from 2022.

events.event_description: Virginia's electricity receipts increased by 61% while California's declined by 39% over a five-year period, driven by data center growth in Virginia and solar adoption in California.
events.citation: Between 2019 and 2023, electricity receipts by Virginia utilities increased by 61% (19.0 million MWh), while California utilities' receipts declined by 39% (27.8 million MWh).
